awd_titl_txt: BPEC: Computational Thinking in STEM: A Whole-School Model for Broadening Participation and Education in Computing
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Summary

NSF STEMC BPEC 1441014: Computational Thinking in STEM: A Whole-School Model for Broadening Participation and Education in Computing

Kai Orton, Michael Horn, Uri Wilensky 

 Northwestern University

 

The Computational Thinking for All (CT4ALL) Project and the Computational Thinking for Girls (CT4G) Clubs are partnerships between Northwestern University, Chicago Public High Schools, and high schools within the greater Chicago region. This project  builds on the previous successes of the Computational Thinking in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (CT-STEM) Project at Northwestern (grants CNS-1441041 & CNS-1138461). The CT4ALL and CT4G partnerships, for the two year BPEC award period, have focused on developing educational programming, enrichment opportunities and teacher capacity at schools with students that are traditionally underrepresented in STEM disciplines. The CT4ALL Project introduces students to integrated computational thinking experiences within their STEM classes that reflect 21st century practices and interdisciplinary perspectives. The CT4G Clubs provide an immersive and collaborative learning environment for exploratory and project-based learning for middle and high school girls focused on a diverse array of activities including robotics, game design, arduino programming, as well as computational creation of music and visual data manipulations. This research study examined the influence of a pilot whole-school model in which computational thinking curricular activities are embedded throughout required biology, chemistry, physics, and mathematics coursework. This approach would ensure that every high school student is exposed to computational literacy activities in a context that demonstrates its relevance to real world career paths. We investigated how such curriculum, as presented in formal STEM classrooms and informal environments like CT4G, affects student and teachers’ attitudes, identity, and learning using surveys, learning assessments, and clinical interviews and observations. The project provides insights into the individual and institutional factors that affect the success of this model in resource-constrained public schools.

 

The general project findings indicate that bringing CT into high school classrooms not only provides an effective strategy for introducing diverse populations of learners to important 21st century skills, it also shifts perceptions of what it means to participate in modern mathematics and scientific  endeavors. Opportunities to engage in CT activities proved to be particularly important for female students’ confidence and positive attitudes towards STEM and future career possibilities. Important influences on positive learning trajectories include engagement, repeated exposures and time-on-task. These findings informed the design of new curriculum and assessment materials developed in the project. The project has contributed to a new technology platform that delivers curriculum and assessments as well as collecting student work for grading by teachers and analysis by the research team.

 

Three CT4ALL partner schools participated in the two year pilot study for whole-school implementation with one of these partner schools also hosting the pilot CT4G Club. Overall, the project provided computational thinking engagement opportunities to hundreds of students in formal STEM classrooms and 82 middle and high school girls participating in CT4G Clubs. Student participants at partner schools self-identified as: Lindblom Math and Science Academy (71% African American, 25% Hispanic, 70% Low Income), Carl Schurz High School (9% African American, 81% Hispanic, 94% Low Income), and Evanston Township High School (30% African American, 15% Hispanic, 41% Low Income). The research has involved seventeen teachers in professional development to implement computational thinking curriculum and learning assessments in their classrooms. This project contributed to 24 stand-alone classroom lessons which have been published on our website (http://ct-stem.northwestern.edu) that integrate computational thinking (CT) into science and math disciplines. In addition, we developed and piloted fifteen project-based learning activities in CT4G Clubs. Work under this grant contributed to 13 peer-reviewed publications including journal articles, conference presentations, and dissertations that report on specific results of project initiatives.


 

 


Last Modified: 01/15/2018
Modified by: Kai Orton
